results.title: Women of the iron frontier
results.creator_credit: Lilias Fraser, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Fraser Film and Video
results.brief_description: Filmed in the remote Pilbara region in far north Western Australia this is a moving revelation of the struggle of women who are trying to create a life for themselves in the hostile environment of outback iron ore mining towns. “Time goes very slowly” deals with the problems of isolation and unemployment for women in Newman. “It’s not a community anymore” tells of the ongoing effects of the bitter 1986 Robe River industrial dispute upon families in the town of Wickham. “It’s supposed to be a town” explores racism through the eyes of both the black and white women of Newman.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lilias Fraser, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Fraser Film and Video

results.title: [Remix: Transport]
results.brief_description: This short film is a remix of archival footage from the ACMI Collection, focusing on public transport in Victoria. The remix contains footage of trams, trains, Flinders Street Station and city streets in Melbourne.

results.title: Don't Shoot the Messenger
results.brief_description: “Visuals recorded live at a digital meditation in cyberspace performed during the Mayday dance party 1993. A series of computers and cameras were interconnected, manipulated realtime and projected.” Sourced from VHS cover slip for Don’t Shoot the Messenger

results.title: [The White continent]
results.brief_description:
Please be advised, this film contains graphic footage of animal cruelty.

In late 1949, a joint expedition planned by the Governments of Britain, Norway and Sweden left for Queen Maude Land on the Antarctic continent - this was to be the first truly international expedition to the Antarctic. The film covers the first stage of the journey, from departure point in Europe to the establishment of the base camps and later withdrawal of the ship’s party, leaving the groups of scientists to their study of the unknown world of ice and snow. Photography by Tom Stobart.

results.title: The Memory of Water (part 1)
results.credit_line: Video excerpt and still images on this page are provided courtesy of the artist.
results.brief_description:
The ‘Memory of Water (part 1)’ explores Carl Jung’s notion of the ‘collective unconscious’, examining consciousness in the form of memory or perceived experience and the power of the gaze as that which mediates external phenomena. Sadia’s video explores the relationship between the drop and the ocean in terms of human experience. While the camera is trained in close up on their eyes, a series of people answer the question, “What is your most significant memory?”

The words and the eyes are played out of sync, so that one person’s voice speaks under another’s gaze. This simple device releases the memories from individual ownership, and the work becomes a gesture towards transcendence. Informed by the Jungian notion of the collective unconscious, The Memory of Water examines the gaze as a bridge between inner and outer worlds.

results.title: Audiences left laughing at bad CGI
results.brief_description: Streaming site Hulu’s long awaiting movie Death on the Nile has gone viral as viewers question the quality of the CGI. Based on an Agatha Christie novel, the murder mystery is set in 1930s Egypt but was predominately shot in the UK. Clips of the worst offending scene have been shared online and retweeted almost 9,000 times, with viewers likening the special effects to low budget productions of the 1990s. Some defended its use, explaining that it was made at the height of the pandemic when people couldn’t travel, while others wondered if it was a ‘stylistic nod’ to the sound stages of Old Hollywood.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Streaming site Hulu’s long awaiting movie Death on the Nile has gone viral as viewers question the quality of the CGI. Clips of the worst offending scene have been shared online and retweeted almost 9,000 times, with viewers likening the special effects to low budget productions of the 1990s. Some defended its use, explaining that it was made at the height of the pandemic when people couldn’t travel, while others wondered if it was a ‘stylistic nod’ to the sound stages of Old Hollywood.

results.title: Round the Twist: Series 1
results.creator_credit: Paul Jennings, Esben Storm, Patricia Edgar and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
An international award winning Australian comedy series based on the stories of celebrated children’s author, Paul Jennings. Each of the stories told in the thirteen self-contained episodes of Series 1 follows the adventures of the Twist kids – Pete, Linda, Bronson – who have moved to the coastal town of Port Niranda with their Dad. Living in a haunted lighthouse, they encounter bizarre magical devices, neurotic ghosts, rampaging entrepreneurs and sneering school bullies.
A uniquely quirky kid’s TV series loved by generations of the young-at-heart.

results.title: Round the twist: Wunderpants
results.creator_credit: Paul Jennings, Steve Steve Jodrell, Antonia Barnard and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description: When Pete dries his underpants in the microwave, special powers are conveyed with embarrassing consequences. But when Pete’s frog competes in the jumping competition, the wunderpants save the day.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Jennings, Steve Steve Jodrell, Antonia Barnard and Australian Children’s Television Foundation

results.title: Round the twist: without my pants
results.creator_credit: Paul Jennings, Esben Storm, Antonia Barnard and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description: Pete is inflicted with a bizarre speech defect. He compulsively adds the words “without my pants” to the end of every sentence with hilarious and embarrassing results.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Jennings, Esben Storm, Antonia Barnard and Australian Children’s Television Foundation

results.title: Round the twist: the gum-leaf war
results.creator_credit: Paul Jennings, Steve Steve Jodrell, Antonia Barnard and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description: Dreaming that she has a huge nose, Linda takes her problems to Aunt Tuneless’ shack in the mountains where a war is in progress. People can inflict their own ailments on others by playing the gum leaves from a twisted tree.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Jennings, Steve Steve Jodrell, Antonia Barnard and Australian Children’s Television Foundation
